page:
Nominal Phrases - Articles and Demonstratives: Examples and Case Now consider articles and demonstratives. In English, the articles are a, an, and the. English demonstratives include this, that, these, and those. Some simple examples are:
a book. an apple. the book. the books. this apple. those books.
In English, articles and demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, and both occur before the noun. They may be able to co-occur in your language, or they may occur in different positions with respect to the noun. Therefore, we will give them different syntactic categories. Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as independent words.
RNPArtAndDem
Does your language have articles and/or demonstratives realized as independent words? If your language uses a form of the number ‘one’ as an indefinite article, check that you have articles. No, neither one Only articles, no demonstratives Only demonstratives, no articles Yes, both articles and demonstratives
RNPArtDefOnly
Is one of the articles unmarked in your language? No, both the definite and indefinite articles are overt words Yes, only the definite article is overt; indefinite nouns are not modified by an article Yes, only the indefinite article is overt (possibly being a form of the number 'one'); definite nouns are not modified by an article
RNPArtPl
Does your language have different forms for singular and plural articles to agree with the noun? No, there is only one set of definite indefinitearticles Yes, there are distinct forms for singular and plural
RNPDemPl
Does your language have different forms for singular and plural demonstratives to agree with the noun? No, there is only one set of demonstratives Yes, there are distinct forms for singular and plural
RArtCase
Does your language have different forms for articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives based on case? No Yes
RNPArtAndDemClassifierAgr
You said that your language has classifiers which mark concord agreement throughout the nominal phrases. Do the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives have classifiers attached to them? No, these elements are not marked with classifiers Yes, these elements are marked with classifiers as part of the concord agreement system
Since you have already detailed the forms of the classifiers, you only need to enter the roots for each of the articlesdemonstrativesarticles and demonstratives here. However, include the clasifiers when giving examples of full nominal phrases below.
Since your language does not distinguish case, you should have only a single set of articles that can be used in any position in the sentence.
Key the definite articles your language uses in the text box, each on a separate line:
Key the indefinite articles your language uses in the text box, each on a separate line:

In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the articles that occur in subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the articles that occur in objects.
Add the feature genitive to all the articles that occur in possessors.
If a particular article can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
Since your language has an ergative-absolutive case system, you should have distinct sets of articles that can be used in subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs versus possessors.

In the lexicon:
Add the feature ergative to all the articles that occur in subjects of transitive verbs.
Add the feature absolutive to all the articles that occur in objects of transitive verbs and in subjects of intransitive verbs.
Add the feature genitive to all the articles that occur in possessors.
If a particular article can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
Since your language has a split case system, you should have distinct sets of articles that are normally used in subjects and objects and possessors, plus some special sets which are used in the split ergativity cases.

In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the articles that occur in subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the articles that occur in objects.
Add the feature genitive to all the articles that occur in possessors.
For the split ergativity cases, add the feature ergative to all the articles that can only occur in subjects of transitive verbs and add the feature absolutive to all the articles that can only occur in subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. Note that if there is some overlap between the sets for nominative-accusative versus ergative-absolutive, you will probably need to have two entries in your lexicon for those articles, each marked with the appropriate case feature.
If a particular article can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
You should also have an additional set of articles to use in indirect objects and subjects of Experiencer verbs.

In the lexicon, add the feature dative to all the articles that occur in indirect objects or Experiencer subjects.

Since your language has a nominative-accusative case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives that go with subjects with the feature nominative and those that go with direct objects with the feature accusative.
If you have a set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can occur in a subject or in a possessor but not in the object of a verb or , add the feature nominative.or.genitive.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can occur in a subject or in an object but not in a possessor, add the feature nominative.or.accusative.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can occur in an object or in a possessor, but not in a subject, add the feature accusative.or.genitive.
Since your language has an ergative-absolutive case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives that go with subjects of transitive verbs with the feature ergative and those that go with direct objects and subjects of intransitive verbs with the feature absolutive.
If you have a distinct set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries, but if either the ergative or absolutive set is used for possessors as well, do not add any additional feature.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
Since your language has a split ergativity case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives that occur with nominative nouns with the feature nominative and those that occur with accusative nouns with the feature accusative.
Mark the articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives that occur with ergative nouns with the feature ergative and those that occur with absolutive nouns with the feature absolutive.
If you have a distinct set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries.
If a particular article demonstrative article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
You should also have an additional set of demonstratives to use in indirect objects and subjects of Experiencer verbs.
